class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbduna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbduna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">In today’s threat environment, adversaries are constantly profiling and attacking your corporate infrastructure to access and collect your intellectual property, proprietary data, and trade secrets. Now, more than ever, Threat Intelligence is increasingly important for organizations who want to proactively defend against advanced threat actors.

While many organizations today are collecting massive amount of threat intelligence, are they able to translate the information into an effective defense strategy?

View the slides now to learn about threat intelligence for operational purposes, including real-world demonstrations of how to consume intelligence and integrate it with existing security infrastructure.

Learn how to prioritize response by differentiating between commodity and targeted attacks and develop a defense that responds to specific methods used by advanced attackers.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1una7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1una7f6"></div></div><!--/$--></div></div><div class="BelowReaderAd_root__NKeGg" Spies: What CTI Analysts Can Learn Fro...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:0" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt=" Intelligence Failures of Lincolns Top Spies: What CTI Analysts Can Learn Fro..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/intelligencefailuresoflincolnstopspies-220406000928-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt=" Intelligence Failures of Lincolns Top Spies: What CTI Analysts Can Learn Fro..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/intelligencefailuresoflincolnstopspies-220406000928-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title"> Intelligence Failures of Lincolns Top Spies: What CTI Analysts Can Learn Fro...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save  Intelligence Failures of Lincolns Top Spies: What CTI Analysts Can Learn Fro... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd1c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd1c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd1c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd1c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd1c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Selena Larson discussed Allan Pinkerton&#x27;s failures as a Union intelligence chief during the Civil War due to poorly vetted information, biased sources, and ineffective communication in long-winded reports. In contrast, the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework can help analysts standardize threat intelligence reporting to produce concise, actionable summaries and mappings of adversary techniques for a variety of audiences. When reviewing third-party data, analysts should critically examine source visibility, evidence basis, and potential biases to produce reliable intelligence.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R11c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R11c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-1" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R12c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R12c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R12c9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/attck-metaverse-exploring-the-limitations-of-applying-attck/251521528"><span class="sr-only">ATT&amp;CK Metaverse - Exploring the Limitations of Applying ATT&amp;CK</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:1" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="ATT&amp;CK Metaverse - Exploring the Limitations of Applying ATT&amp;CK" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/attckmetaverse-exploringthelimitationsofapplyingattck-220406000927-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="ATT&amp;CK Metaverse - Exploring the Limitations of Applying ATT&amp;CK" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/attckmetaverse-exploringthelimitationsofapplyingattck-220406000927-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">ATT&amp;CK Metaverse - Exploring the Limitations of Applying ATT&amp;CK</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save ATT&amp;CK Metaverse - Exploring the Limitations of Applying ATT&amp;CK for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd2c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd2c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd2c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd2c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd2c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Gert-Jan Bruggink, Venation

Since it&#x27;s inception in 2015, the ATT&amp;CK framework has achieved widespread adoption, with recent studies suggesting over 80 percent of companies using the framework for cyber security. Over the last seven years, a variety of use cases has been explored with different measures of success. In this presentation, Gert-Jan will explore applying the ATT&amp;CK framework in scenario-based defense. 

When adopting a scenario approach, security teams collaborate to fuse their understanding of certain situations into scenarios. For example, addressing different hypotheses that can be explained to leadership and specialist teams alike. This approach requires more than &quot;just&quot; breaking down everything into tactics, techniques, and procedures. Some stakeholders might not understand that. For example, some might want to tell a good story about adversaries while others want to translate their understanding of intrusions into a sequential pattern. 

The objective of this talk is to explore how the granularity of the framework supports creation of scenarios, the limitations in the current approach to ATT&amp;CK when building scenarios across different stakeholders, and addressing potential areas the &quot;language of ATT&amp;CK&quot; can evolve towards over the next 5 years.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R12c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R12c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-2" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R13c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R13c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R13c9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/introduction-to-exploitation-metasploit/135832768"><span class="sr-only">Introduction To Exploitation &amp; Metasploit</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:2" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Introduction To Exploitation &amp; Metasploit" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/introductiontoexploitationmetasploit-190312092949-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Introduction To Exploitation &amp; Metasploit" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/introductiontoexploitationmetasploit-190312092949-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Introduction To Exploitation &amp; Metasploit</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Introduction To Exploitation &amp; Metasploit for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd3c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd3c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd3c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd3c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd3c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/raghavbisht9">Raghav Bisht</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Penetration testing involves evaluating systems or networks using malicious techniques to identify security vulnerabilities. It is done by exploiting vulnerabilities to gain unauthorized access to sensitive information. Common vulnerabilities arise from design errors, poor configuration, and human error. Penetration testing is conducted to secure government data transfers, protect brands, and find vulnerabilities in applications, operating systems, databases, and network equipment. Metasploit is an open-source framework used for hacking applications and operating systems that contains exploits, payloads, and modules. Msfconsole is an interface used to launch attacks and create listeners in Metasploit.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R13c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R13c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-3" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R14c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R14c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R14c9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/social-engineering-basics-72243122/72243122"><span class="sr-only">Social Engineering Basics</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:3" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Social Engineering Basics" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/europasocialengineeringpresentation-copy-170216192116-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Social Engineering Basics" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/europasocialengineeringpresentation-copy-170216192116-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Social Engineering Basics</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Social Engineering Basics for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd4c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd4c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/LukeRusten">Luke Rusten</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Do you know what social engineering is? Do you know how to protect yourself from attacks? Learn the basics so you can protect your business!</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R14c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R14c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-4" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R15c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R15c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R15c9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/infocyte/the-new-pentest-rise-of-the-compromise-assessment"><span class="sr-only">The New Pentest? Rise of the Compromise Assessment</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:4" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="The New Pentest? Rise of the Compromise Assessment" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/compromiseassessmentbh-fin-180814152657-180814160747-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="The New Pentest? Rise of the Compromise Assessment" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/compromiseassessmentbh-fin-180814152657-180814160747-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">The New Pentest? Rise of the Compromise Assessment</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save The New Pentest? Rise of the Compromise Assessment for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd5c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd5c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd5c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd5c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd5c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/infocyte">Infocyte</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">If an attacker had a foothold in your network today, would you know it?

If they made it past your real-time defense measures (EDR, EPP, AV, UEBA, firewalls, etc.) or an analyst misinterpreted a critical alert, chances are they&#x27;ve entrenched themselves for the long haul. Skilled and organized attackers know long-term persistence in your network is the most critical component to meeting their goal of stealing information, causing damage, or pivoting attacks on other organizations. 

Threat hunting is the proactive practice of finding attackers in your environment before they can cause damage (or at least stop the bleeding from continued exposure). Unfortunately, effective threat hunting practices remain out-of-reach for most organizations due to lack of security infrastructure and qualified people to manage advanced endpoint security solutions.

One solution to this problem is to hire a third party to conduct a periodic assessment geared toward discovery of unauthorized access and compromised systems. This is called a &quot;compromise assessment&quot; and just recently compromise assessments have become one of the most requested services from top security service providers. 

Customers don’t want to just know if they can be hacked (a good penetration tester will generally conclude “yes”) they want to know if they ARE hacked—right now—and if so, what endpoints/hosts/servers on their network are compromised.

In this presentation, which was originally prepared for Black Hat 2018, Chris Gerritz outlines the growing practice of compromise assessments and the best practices being utilized by some of the largest and most sophisticated managed security service providers (MSSPs) with this offering. 

What approaches are most effective?
What data is being utilized?
What are some of the top challenges?

To request a free 100-node compromise assessment or to learn more about Infocyte HUNT — our comprehensive threat hunting platform — and start a free trial, please visit https://try.infocyte.com.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R15c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R15c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-5" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R16c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R16c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R16c9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/mapping-to-mitre-attck-enhancing-operations-through-the-tracking-of-interactive-intrusion-campaignspdf/251521377"><span class="sr-only">Mapping to MITRE ATT&amp;CK: Enhancing Operations Through the Tracking of Interac...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:5" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Mapping to MITRE ATT&amp;CK: Enhancing Operations Through the Tracking of Interac..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/mappingtomitreattckenhancingoperationsthroughthetrackingofinteractiveintrusioncampaigns-220405233746-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Mapping to MITRE ATT&amp;CK: Enhancing Operations Through the Tracking of Interac..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/mappingtomitreattckenhancingoperationsthroughthetrackingofinteractiveintrusioncampaigns-220405233746-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Mapping to MITRE ATT&amp;CK: Enhancing Operations Through the Tracking of Interac...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Mapping to MITRE ATT&amp;CK: Enhancing Operations Through the Tracking of Interac... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd6c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd6c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd6c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd6c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd6c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Jason Wood and Justin Swisher, CrowdStrike

When it comes to understanding and tracking intrusion tradecraft, security teams must have the tools and processes that allow the mapping of hands-on adversary tradecraft. Doing this enables your team to both understand the adversaries and attacks you currently see and observe how these adversaries and attacks evolve over time. This session will explore how a threat hunting team uses MITRE ATT&amp;CK to understand and categorize adversary activity. The team will demonstrate how threat hunters map ATT&amp;CK TTPs by showcasing a recent interactive intrusion against a Linux endpoint and how the framework allowed for granular tracking of tradecraft and enhanced security operations. They will also take a look into the changes in the Linux activity they have observed over time, using the ATT&amp;CK navigator to compare and contrast technique usage. This session will provide insights into how we use MITRE ATT&amp;CK as a powerful resource to track intrusion tradecraft, identify adversary trends, and prepare for attacks of the future.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R16c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R16c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-6" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R17c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R17c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R17c9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/defending-against-the-dark-arts-of-lolbins/238435154"><span class="sr-only">Defending Against the Dark Arts of LOLBINS </span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:6" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A data-cy="slideshow-title">Defending Against the Dark Arts of LOLBINS </span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd7c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd7c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd7c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd7c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd7c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/bsmuir">Brent Muir</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses defending against attacks that use legitimate operating system tools and binaries (&quot;living off the land&quot;) through defense-in-depth strategies. It recommends: 1) application whitelisting policies for high-risk binaries, 2) blocking child processes for those binaries, and 3) restrictive firewall policies. It also provides an overview of exploit protection techniques and tips for maintaining system visibility and inventory records.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R17c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R17c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-7" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R18c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R18c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R18c9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/automation-the-wonderful-wizard-of-cti-or-is-it/250452007"><span class="sr-only">Automation: The Wonderful Wizard of CTI (or is it?) </span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:7" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Automation: The Wonderful Wizard of CTI (or is it?) " src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/automationthewonderfulwizardofctiorisit-211015142951-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Automation: The Wonderful Wizard of CTI (or is it?) " src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/automationthewonderfulwizardofctiorisit-211015142951-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Automation: The Wonderful Wizard of CTI (or is it?) </span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Automation: The Wonderful Wizard of CTI (or is it?)  for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd8c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd8c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd8c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd8c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd8c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document describes MITRE&#x27;s Threat Report Automated Mapper (TRAM) tool, which uses machine learning to automatically map cyber threat reports to MITRE ATT&amp;CK techniques. TRAM aims to streamline the process of analyzing reports and adding information to ATT&amp;CK, though challenges remain around prediction accuracy and identifying new techniques. The document outlines TRAM&#x27;s development process and discusses balancing automation with human analysis to better integrate cyber threat intelligence into ATT&amp;CK.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R18c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R18c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-8" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R19c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R19c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R19c9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/using-mitre-preattck-and-attck-in-cybercrime-education-and-research/241296402"><span class="sr-only">Using MITRE PRE-ATTACK and ATTACK in Cybercrime Education and Research</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:8" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Using MITRE PRE-ATTACK and ATTACK in Cybercrime Education and Research" alt="Using MITRE PRE-ATTACK and ATTACK in Cybercrime Education and Research" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/aunshulrege-210113194534-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Using MITRE PRE-ATTACK and ATTACK in Cybercrime Education and Research</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Using MITRE PRE-ATTACK and ATTACK in Cybercrime Education and Research for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd9c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd9c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd9c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd9c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd9c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/attackcon2018">MITRE - ATT&amp;CKcon</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon Power Hour October 2020

By:
Aunshul Rege, Associate Professor, Temple University, @prof_rege

Rachel Bleiman, PhD Student/NSF Graduate Research Assistant, Temple University, @rab1928

This presentation from the MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon Power Hour session on October 9, 2020, explores the application of the MITRE ATT&amp;CK® and PRE-ATT&amp;CK matrices in cybercrime education and research. Specifically, Rege and Bleiman demonstrate the mapping of the PRE-ATT&amp;CK matrix to social engineering case studies as an experiential learning project in an upper-level cybercrime liberal arts course. It thus allows students to understand the alignment process of threat intelligence to the PRE-ATT&amp;CK framework and also learn about its usefulness/limitations. The talk also discusses the mapping of the ATT&amp;CK matrix, tactics, techniques, software, and groups for two cybercrime datasets created by collating publicly disclosed incidents: (i) critical infrastructure ransomware (CIRW) incidents, and (ii) social engineering (SE) incidents. For the CIRW dataset, 39% of the strains mapped onto the ATT&amp;CK software. For the SE dataset, 49% of the groups and 65% of the techniques map on to the MITRE framework. This helps the researchers identify the framework&#x27;s usefulness/limitations and also helps our datasets connect to richer information that may not otherwise be available in the publicly disclosed incidents.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R19c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R19c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-9" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1ac9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R1ac9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1ac9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/jorgeorchilles">Jorge Orchilles</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Red Teaming is hot right now. Many people want to get into it just because it sounds cool. While I tend to agree, there are many things to consider. There is way more to red teaming than just &quot;getting in&quot; to organizations. Join us for this one hour webcast where we cover what red team is, why you may want to be a red teamer, and how to become a red teamer.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ac9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ac9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-10" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1bc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R1bc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1bc9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/threat-modelling-its-not-just-for-developerspdf/251528613"><span class="sr-only">Threat Modelling - slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/dgsweigert">David Sweigert</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses using an attacker&#x27;s tactics and techniques to design effective cybersecurity defenses. It provides examples of mapping security controls and tools to different stages of common attack models like the Lockheed Martin Kill Chain. This allows an organization to see where in the attack cycle they have visibility and can disrupt threats. The document advocates taking a strategic, intelligence-driven approach to cyber defense by understanding adversaries&#x27; full operations in order to implement controls earlier in the attack cycle.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1cc9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1cc9jnf6"></div><div class="separator style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">It&#x27;s just a jump to the left (of boom): Prioritizing detection implementation...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save It&#x27;s just a jump to the left (of boom): Prioritizing detection implementation... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbddc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbddc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbddc9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbddc9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbddc9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Lindsay Kaye and Scott Small, Recorded Future

Many organizations ask: &quot;Where do I start, and where do I go next&quot; when prioritizing implementation of behavior-based detections? We often hear &quot;use threat intelligence!&quot; but your goals must be qualified and quantified in order to properly prioritize the most relevant TTPs. A wealth of open-sourced, ATT&amp;CK-mapped resources now exists, giving security teams greater access to both detections and red team tests they can implement, but intelligence (also aligned with ATT&amp;CK), is essential to provide necessary context to ensure that detection efforts are focused effectively.
This session will discuss a new approach to the prioritization challenge, starting with an analysis of the current defensive landscape, as measured by ATT&amp;CK coverage for more than a dozen detection repositories and technologies, and guidance on sourcing TTP intelligence. The team will then show how real-world defensive strategies can be strengthened by encompassing a full-spectrum view of threat detection, including the implementation of YARA, Sigma, and Snort in security appliances. Critically, alignment of both intelligence and defenses with ATT&amp;CK enables defenders to move the focus of detection efforts to indications of malicious behavior before the final payload is deployed, where controls are most effective at preventing serious damage to the organization.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1dc9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1dc9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-13" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1ec9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R1ec9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1ec9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/projects-to-impact-operationalizing-work-from-the-center/251521747"><span class="sr-only">Projects to Impact- Operationalizing Work from the Center</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:13" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a data-cy="slideshow-title">Projects to Impact- Operationalizing Work from the Center</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdec9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdec9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The Center for Threat-Informed Defense conducts collaborative R&amp;D projects to improve cyber defense. The Center&#x27;s work includes developing standardized adversary emulation plans, mapping vulnerabilities to adversary tactics and techniques, and creating tools to help organizations integrate threat information. All of the Center&#x27;s project outputs are made freely available to help defenders worldwide.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ec9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ec9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-14" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1fc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R1fc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1fc9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/zero-day-exploits-63613638/63613638"><span class="sr-only">zero day exploits</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:14" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="zero day exploits" Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="zero day exploits" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/e626f243-62f7-475f-9355-2f6c1aa8dbc0-160630152841-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">zero day exploits</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save zero day exploits for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdfc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdfc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdfc9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdfc9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdfc9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/AdvPrashantMaliBscPh">Adv. Prashant Mali ♛ [Bsc(Phy),MSc(Comp Sci), CCFP,CISSA,LLM]</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">A zero day vulnerability is an unknown hole in software that is exploited by hackers before the vendor becomes aware of it. These exploits can go undetected for months, allowing malicious activities like monitoring or theft. There is high demand for zero day exploits due to their ability to go undetected for long periods, with the average exploit remaining undetected for over 300 days. Once a vulnerability is publicly known, patches can be released and it is no longer considered a zero day exploit.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1fc9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1fc9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-15" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1gc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R1gc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1gc9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" class="sr-only">Exploring how Students Map Social Engineering Techniques to the ATT&amp;CK Framew...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:15" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Exploring how Students Map Social Engineering style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Exploring how Students Map Social Engineering Techniques to the ATT&amp;CK Framew...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Exploring how Students Map Social Engineering Techniques to the ATT&amp;CK Framew... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdgc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdgc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdgc9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdgc9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdgc9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Aunshul Rege, Katorah Williams, and Rachel Bleiman, Temple University

Social engineering (SE) is a technique used by cybercriminals to psychologically manipulate individuals into disclosing sensitive information and providing unauthorized access. Penetration testers are tasked with simulating targeted attacks on a company&#x27;s system to determine any weaknesses in their environment. 

The 2021 Summer SE Pen Test Competition allowed students to experience SE pen testing in a safe and ethical way. Student teams were &quot;hired&quot; to conduct a SE pen test on the CARE Lab (run by the authors) and their employees (the authors themselves)! Teams had to use OSINT, phishing, and vishing in real-time to target the lab, develop attack playbooks, and map the techniques to the ATT&amp;CK framework. 

This talk shares the application of ATT&amp;CK in cybersecurity education. Specifically, it (i) focuses on how students map their SE attack playbooks to the ATT&amp;CK framework, (ii) compares/contrasts SE techniques across various student groups: 6 graduate teams, 9 undergraduate teams, and 1 high school team, and (iii) how ATT&amp;CK can be used for SE.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1gc9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1gc9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-16" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1hc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R1hc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1hc9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/the-cyber-threat-intelligence-matrix/67745151"><span class="sr-only">The Cyber Threat Intelligence Matrix</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:16" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="The Cyber Threat Intelligence Matrix" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/2016-10274sicsthe-cyber-threat-intelligence-matrixfrode-hommedaltelenor-161027190146-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="The Cyber Threat Intelligence Matrix" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/2016-10274sicsthe-cyber-threat-intelligence-matrixfrode-hommedaltelenor-161027190146-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">The Cyber Threat Intelligence Matrix</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save The Cyber Threat Intelligence Matrix for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdhc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdhc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdhc9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdhc9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdhc9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/FrodeHommedal">Frode Hommedal</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">As we get to know what life in the digital domain is like, one of the revelations we&#x27;ve had is that many large and plenty of smaller organisations are targets of espionage, of the nefarious APT.

During the last decade, it has become gospel to wait, watch, analyse and learn if you detect such an attacker in your infrastructure. Why? Because you get one chance to do the eviction of the attacker right. And if you fail, all your efforts will eventually have been for nothing.

But for how long should you wait and watch? When have you watched long enough? When have you learned enough? And how do you make that decision?

That is the challenge I hope the Cyber Threat Intelligence Matrix can help you face in a more structured manner.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1hc9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1hc9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-17" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1ic9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R1ic9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1ic9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/supply-chainattack/173722356"><span class="sr-only">Supply chain-attack</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:17" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img alt="Supply chain-attack" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/supply-chain-attack-190919124014-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Supply chain-attack</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Supply chain-attack for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdic9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdic9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdic9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdic9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdic9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/vikramvashisth">vikram vashisth</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Supply chain attacks target software developers and suppliers by infecting legitimate applications to distribute malware. Attackers can compromise developer Git accounts to inject malware into repositories that get delivered to clients. They can also introduce vulnerable modules that aren&#x27;t properly tested. This can lead to financial and personal data theft for customers of affected e-commerce sites, and legal issues for site owners and software vendors due to data breaches and loss of trust. Detecting malware involves scanning modules, servers, and developer systems using tools like YARA, LMD, and SYNK at various stages of the software development and delivery process.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ic9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ic9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-18" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1jc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R1jc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1jc9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/putting-mitre-attck-into-action-with-what-you-have-where-you-are/143650354"><span class="sr-only">Putting MITRE ATT&amp;CK into Action with What You Have, Where You Are</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:18" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Putting MITRE ATT&amp;CK into Action with What You Have, Where You Are" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/nickels-sp4rkcon-mitreattck-190504152848-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Putting MITRE ATT&amp;CK into Action with What You Have, Where You Are" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/nickels-sp4rkcon-mitreattck-190504152848-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Putting MITRE ATT&amp;CK into Action with What You Have, Where You Are</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Putting MITRE ATT&amp;CK into Action with What You Have, Where You Are for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdjc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdjc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdjc9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdjc9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdjc9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/KatieNickels">Katie Nickels</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document provides an overview of Katie Nickels&#x27; presentation on putting MITRE ATT&amp;CK into action using available resources. Some key points include:
- MITRE ATT&amp;CK is a knowledge base of adversary tactics and techniques based on real-world observations. 
- It can be used for detection, assessment, threat intelligence, and adversary emulation.
- For detection, ATT&amp;CK can help improve focus on post-exploit activity and track gaps/improvements in coverage over time. Existing data sources can be leveraged to detect techniques.
- For assessment and engineering, ATT&amp;CK can guide decisions around tool selection and help identify visibility and risk acceptance gaps.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1jc9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1jc9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes a CrowdStrike webinar on detecting advanced malware-free intrusions. It describes three speakers from CrowdStrike - Dmitri Alperovitch, Chris Scott, and Adam Meyers. The webinar then discusses how adversaries like China and various state-sponsored and criminal groups are adapting their tactics to evade detection, and how security teams must also adapt detection methods to focus on real-time monitoring rather than indicators of compromise. The webinar includes a case study of detecting a webshell attack in near real-time using CrowdStrike Falcon Host and concludes with a demonstration of its endpoint protection capabilities.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R11cajnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R11cajnf6"></div><div class="separator class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">In today’s threat environment, adversaries are constantly profiling and attacking your corporate infrastructure to access and collect your intellectual property, proprietary data, and trade secrets. Now, more than ever, Threat Intelligence is increasingly important for organizations who want to proactively defend against advanced threat actors.

While many organizations today are collecting massive amount of threat intelligence, are they able to translate the information into an effective defense strategy?

View the slides now to learn about threat intelligence for operational purposes, including real-world demonstrations of how to consume intelligence and integrate it with existing security infrastructure.

Learn how to prioritize response by differentiating between commodity and targeted attacks and develop a defense that responds to specific methods used by advanced attackers.</span></div></div><div RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Michael Saylor is the executive director of Cyber Defense Labs at UT Dallas. The document discusses current cyber security trends and emerging threats. Recent trends in 2013 included an increase in attacks with web and social engineering components as well as politically motivated DDoS attacks. Mobile devices and applications are increasingly being targeted, as are advanced persistent threats from groups like China&#x27;s APT1. Emerging threats discussed include the potential for increased cyber crime and terrorism from groups funded by drug cartels and foreign states. The document recommends best practices for organizations like user education, monitoring, encryption, and frequent security assessments.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R13cajnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R13cajnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" Threats_The Current Risks and Mitigation...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:3" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/LumensionSecurity">Lumension</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">APTs have become a major topic of conversation – and in some cases, a critical threat – among IT security departments. But the technology and motivation behind APTs has changed significantly since the introduction of Stuxnet, continuing to evolve rapidly to avoid detection. 
In this special Dark Reading presentation, a leading expert on the origins and directions of APTs will discuss the changing nature of these sophisticated threats – and how you can prepare your enterprise security environment to detect and mitigate these complex and dangerous attacks.

RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The FBI is tasked with protecting the US from cyber threats including cybercrime, espionage, and terrorism. The document outlines various cyber threats such as phishing schemes, botnets, and malware infections. It also describes the FBI&#x27;s response which includes investigating cases, sharing intelligence through task forces and information portals, and advising but not directly assisting victims. International cooperation is needed to address cyber threats effectively.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R16cajnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R16cajnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="similarTo-card-description-6" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R17cajnf6:" popovertarget=":R17cajnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R17cajnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/trend-micro-is-your-cloud-secure/16776407"><span class="sr-only">Trend Micro - is your cloud secure</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Trend Micro - is your cloud secure for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd7cajnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd7cajnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd7cajnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd7cajnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd7cajnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Kappadata">Kappa Data </a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses the need for organizations to have a smart protection strategy to secure their cloud environments from cyber threats. It notes that threats are becoming more challenging due to trends like cloud/virtualization, consumerization, and the actions of employees. An effective strategy uses global threat intelligence from multiple sources to detect both known and unknown threats. It advocates for network-wide detection, custom sandboxes for analysis, and automated security updates. The strategy aims to provide advanced, targeted protection while remaining simple to manage and deploy.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R17cajnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R17cajnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">KASPERSKY SECURITY BULLETIN 2013</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd8cajnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd8cajnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Kappadata">Kappa Data </a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Once again, it’s time for Kaspersky to deliver our customary retrospective of the key events that have defined the threat landscape in 2013. Let’s start by looking back at the things we thought would shape the year ahead, based on the trends we observed in the previous year. </span></div></div><div class="" id=":R18cajnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R18cajnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="similarTo-card-description-8" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R19cajnf6:" popovertarget=":R19cajnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R19cajnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/cb19-from-advanced-persistent-threats-to-advanced-persistent-manipulators-the-evolving-cyber-defense-battlefield-by-mei-nelson/204343930"><span class="sr-only">[CB19] From Advanced Persistent Threats to &quot;Advanced Persistent Manipulators&quot;...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:8" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="[CB19] From Advanced Persistent Threats to &quot;Advanced Persistent Manipulators&quot;..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/idefensemeinelsoncodeblue19slidedeck20191125public-191211072501-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="[CB19] From Advanced Persistent Threats to &quot;Advanced Persistent Manipulators&quot;..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/idefensemeinelsoncodeblue19slidedeck20191125public-191211072501-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">[CB19] From Advanced Persistent Threats to &quot;Advanced Persistent Manipulators&quot;...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save [CB19] From Advanced Persistent Threats to &quot;Advanced Persistent Manipulators&quot;... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd9cajnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd9cajnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd9cajnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd9cajnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd9cajnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/codeblue_jp">CODE BLUE</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">As advanced persistent threats (APTs) have become pervasive, governments and organizations have spent billions of dollars over the years fighting them. Meanwhile, actors have created a new breed of threat – “Advanced Persistent Manipulators” (APMs), to borrow a term coined by scholar Clint Watts at the Alliance for Securing Democracy in the United States. APMs have learned from APTs’ successes and taken advantage of the developments in information technology with an aim of manipulating information and influencing decision making.
This presentation will explore Advanced Persistent Manipulator threats through a comparative study with advanced persistent threats. This comparison will examine motives, goals, and tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs) related to each. It will further review the unique characteristics of APMs and current regulatory environments that affect efforts to defend against disinformation. Lastly, this presentation will offer countermeasures that governments and private organizations may want to consider when developing plans for defense against APM threats in the current and evolving threat environment.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R19cajnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R19cajnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="similarTo-card-description-9" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1acajnf6:" popovertarget=":R1acajnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1acajnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/netscout-threat-report-2018/109428518"><span class="sr-only">Netscout threat report 2018</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:9" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Netscout threat report slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/BogaelTech">Gabe Akisanmi</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">NETSCOUT Arbor released its 2018 NETSCOUT Threat Intelligence Report offering globally scoped internet threat intelligence together with the analysis of our security research organization. The report covers the latest trends and activities from nation-state advanced persistent threat (APT) groups, crimeware operations and Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack campaigns.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1acajnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1acajnf6"></div><div class="separator data-cy="slideshow-title">Cyber Conflict</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Cyber Conflict for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdbcajnf6:" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdbcajnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdbcajnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/tony.ridley">Enterprise Security Risk Management</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses how individuals and organizations can become unintended targets in cyber conflicts. It notes that cyber attacks often follow physical protests and tensions between countries. It provides tips on how to identify potential targeting through monitoring related physical protests, cyber attacks against similar organizations, and controversial business decisions. The document also categorizes different types of targets and their likelihood of facing short or long-term attacks. It closes by questioning if standard cyber defenses are sufficient against sophisticated, persistent threats.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1bcajnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1bcajnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" aria-describedby="similarTo-card-description-11" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1ccajnf6:" popovertarget=":R1ccajnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1ccajnf6"><a
